prompt_template: Fill the blanks for EIS and SEIS income tax relief: EIS subscriptions up to {gap1} get {gap2} relief; SEIS subscriptions up to {gap3} get {gap4} relief (each subject to the ‘lower of’ liability cap).
explanation: EIS: up to £1,000,000 at 30%; SEIS: up to £200,000 at 50% (both as tax reducers capped by the individual’s income tax liability).

prompt_template: Complete the timing conditions for reinvestment relief: EIS deferral relief is available when qualifying EIS shares are acquired within {gap1} year before and {gap2} years after the disposal of a chargeable asset. SEIS reinvestment relief requires reinvestment during {gap3}.
gap3_options: ["the same tax year", "the following tax year", "any time within 3 years"]
explanation: : EIS reinvestment (deferral) window is 1 year before to 3 years after disposal; SEIS reinvestment relief requires reinvestment in qualifying SEIS shares during the same tax year.

prompt_template: Small entity + IR35 applies: the PSC must calculate a {gap1}; {gap2} cannot be used; dividends {gap3} the deemed salary and are {gap4} taxed as dividends; and the deemed salary is deemed paid on the {gap5} of the tax year.
explanation: for small entities: a deemed salary is calculated; employment allowance cannot be used; dividends form part of the deemed salary and are not taxed separately as dividends; deemed salary is treated as paid on the last day of the tax year.

prompt_template: Medium/large entity + IR35 applies: the {gap1} determines status and issues an {gap2}. The individual may challenge, and the client has {gap3} days to respond. The deemed direct payment is taxed like employment income, and to avoid double tax the {gap4} is deducted before computing further IT/NIC when the PSC later pays salary/dividends.
explanation: : for medium/large entities the client determines IR35 and issues an SDS; there is a 45-day challenge/response window; the DDP is taxed like employment and is deducted to prevent double taxation when PSC later remunerates the individual.

prompt_template: Match the terms to the definitions: Grant = {gap1}; Exercise = {gap2}; Disposal = {gap3}.
gap1_options: ["date the right to buy starts","date employee buys the shares","date employee sells the shares"]
gap1_correct: date the right to buy starts
gap2_options: ["date employee buys the shares","date employee sells the shares","date the right to buy starts"]
gap3_options: ["date employee sells the shares","date employee buys the shares","date the right to buy starts"]
explanation: Grant is when the option is granted (right to buy starts), exercise is when the employee buys the shares, and disposal is when the employee sells the shares.

prompt_template: Fill in the limits/timings: Under Company Share Option Plan (CSOP) the max option value per employee is {gap1} and options must be exercised between {gap2} and {gap3} years. Under Enterprise Management Incentive schemes (EMI), the employee limit is {gap4} and the total company grant limit is {gap5}.
explanation: : Company Share Option Plan (CSOP) limit £60,000 and exercise window 3–10 years. Enterprise Management Incentive schemes (EMI) limits: £250,000 per employee and £3m total company grant.

prompt_template: Share Incentive Plan (SIP) withdrawal charges: If shares are held in the Share Incentive Plan (SIP) for more than {gap1} years, there is no IT or NIC on withdrawal. If held for less than {gap2} years, IT and NIC are based on {gap3} at withdrawal. If held between {gap4} and {gap5} years, the IT/NIC charge is based on the lower of MV at award vs MV at withdrawal.
explanation: : Share Incentive Plan (SIP) >5 years: no IT/NIC on taking shares out. <3 years: IT/NIC based on market value at withdrawal. 3–5 years: IT/NIC based on the lower of MV at award and MV at withdrawal.

prompt_template: Split-year treatment can divide the tax year into a UK part ({gap1}) and an overseas part ({gap2}).
explanation: Your notes explicitly define UK part taxable and overseas part not taxable.

prompt_template: Leaving-UK split-year cases include leaving to begin {gap1} work overseas, and leaving to accompany a {gap2} starting full-time work overseas.
explanation: The leaving cases include starting full-time overseas work yourself or accompanying a spouse who does so.

prompt_template: For the “to live abroad” leaving case to apply, the tests are whether the taxpayer is selling the {gap1} house, spending {gap2} time in UK, and keeping ties with another {gap3}.
explanation: This case requires selling UK house, minimal UK presence, and ties with another country.

prompt_template: A coming-to-UK split-year case applies where an individual acquires a UK {gap1} and did not have sufficient {gap2} to be UK resident before that acquisition.
explanation: Your notes state acquiring a UK home with insufficient pre-existing ties can qualify.

prompt_template: Another coming case is arrival to work {gap1} in the UK for at least {gap2}, without sufficient ties for UK residence before arrival.
explanation: The notes require full-time UK work for at least one year in this coming case.

prompt_template: A return-to-UK case can apply after a period where {gap1} or their spouse worked {gap2} overseas.
explanation: Your notes include return following a period of full-time overseas work by the individual or spouse.

prompt_template: Automatic overseas test (prior UK resident): in UK fewer than {gap1} days and UK resident in one or more previous {gap2} tax years.
explanation: This test uses <16 days and prior residence in at least one of the previous 3 tax years.

prompt_template: Automatic overseas test (not recently UK resident): in UK fewer than {gap1} days and not resident during previous {gap2} tax years.
explanation: For those not resident in the prior three tax years, the threshold is <46 days.

prompt_template: Automatic UK tests include: UK presence of {gap1} days or more, and only home in UK occupied for at least {gap2} days.
explanation: Automatic UK tests in your notes include 183+ days and the only-home test with at least 30 days occupation.

prompt_template: Sufficient ties: accommodation tie requires UK house available for at least {gap1} days; work tie is {gap2}+ UK work days; historic-day tie looks at >{gap3} UK days in either of previous two tax years.
explanation: These three sufficient ties thresholds are 91, 40, and >90 days respectively.

prompt_template: Domicile types: domicile of {gap1} is inherited from father at birth; domicile of {gap2} applies while under 16 if father’s domicile changes; domicile of {gap3} arises after 16 when old ties are severed and person settles permanently overseas.
explanation: The sequence is origin, dependency, then choice.

prompt_template: Deemed domicile routes: long-term resident test is UK residence in at least {gap1} of previous {gap2} tax years; formerly UK domiciled resident route requires birth in UK, UK domicile of origin, and UK residence in the {gap3} tax year.
explanation: Long-term route is 15/20; formerly UK domiciled resident route includes UK residence in the relevant tax year.

prompt_template: For IHT deemed domicile at transfer time, meeting any {gap1} of {gap2} listed conditions is sufficient.
explanation: The framework is any one of three conditions.

prompt_template: Condition 1: individual was domiciled in the UK within the {gap1} years immediately {gap2} that time.
explanation: The first trigger is UK domicile within the 3 years immediately preceding the transfer time.

prompt_template: Formerly UK domiciled individual route requires: born in {gap1}, UK domicile of {gap2}, UK resident in relevant year, and UK resident in at least {gap3} of previous {gap4} tax years.
explanation: This route combines birthplace, domicile-origin, current-year residence and a 1-of-2 prior-year residence test.

prompt_template: UK-resident deemed-domicile route uses residence for at least {gap1} of previous {gap2} years and at least {gap3} of the {gap4} years ending with relevant year.
explanation: This route combines 15/20 with a 1/4 recency condition.

prompt_template: To distinguish IHT from CGT/IT revision, memorise the IHT windows: {gap1} years (domicile lookback), {gap2} of {gap3}, and {gap4} of {gap5}.
explanation: The key IHT memory anchors are 3-year lookback, 15/20, and 1/4.

prompt_template: For IHT, deemed domicile is tested at the time a {gap1} is made, not just at tax-year {gap2}.
explanation: The trigger point in the note is the transfer time.

prompt_template: Double taxation relief is the {gap1} of overseas tax paid and UK HT atrributable to the overseas asset. UK IHT is calculated as {gap2}/(gap3} x {gap4}.
gap2_options: ["UK IHT before QSR","UK IHT after QSR","Taxable estate","overseas tax paid"]
gap3_options: ["Chargeable estate","Taxable estate","overseas tax paid","UK IHT before QSR"]
gap4_options: ["UK IHT before QSR","Chargeable estate","Overseas tax paid","Value of asset"]
explanation: Double taxation relief is the lower of overseas tax paid and UK IHT atrributable to the overseas asset. UK IHT is calculated as UK IHT after QSR/Chargeable estate x value of asset
